title.narrative: F.a: Support for Miskito self-governance in Watiasta and Lainasta

description.narrative: The project strengthens the governance of two indigenous Miskito territories (Watiasta and Lainasta) in the Honduran Mosquitia by constructing natural resource management protocols rooted in the communities? cosmovision. The Honduran government is committe d to granting collective land titles to the 12 Miskito territorial councils. Owing to decades of delay in titling the lands, the area has been invaded by aggressive intruders, who deforest for cattle ranching and sell the lands to new intruders. The projec t continues MASTA?s work in favour of materializing the collective rights of the Miskito and autonomous governance of their territories. The natural resource management protocols provide an essential tool for defining how the lands titled by the government to the Miskito are governed. The processes to be implemented in Watiasta and Lainasta follow a similar process already implemented within another territory. MASTA is a community rooted Miskito organisation founded in 1976 and registered in 1987. It aims t o i) strengthen the autonomy of Mosquitia and the indigenous territorial governance, ii) advocate towards the national decision-makers to guarantee the historical rights of the indigenous peoples and the application of international treaties on indigenous peoples' rights, as well as iii) defend the legal recognition of Miskitos' collective rights to govern their land, territories and natural resources. Through active advocacy in the past few years, MASTA has succeeded in legalising the territories of seven regional Miskito councils (in total 772 000 hectares) and all the 12 councils have gained legal status. Miskitos have developed their own consultation protocol (Protocolo Biocultural Miskito), which is applied in organising a consultation when an outside a ctor wishes to implement an initiative in Mosquitia. Furthermore, functioning of the regional councils has been strengthened, guidelines for natural resource use have been established for one region, and the participation of women in MASTA's decision-makin g has been strengthened.
